subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Group
msgSnippet: I (a Dutch guy 17 years old) once (a few months ago) had the idea of creating (with the help of others, perhaps) a program which could convert Traditional
messageBody:
I (a Dutch guy 17 years old) once (a few months ago) had the idea of
creating (with the help of others, perhaps) a program which could
convert Traditional Orthography Texts directly to Quikscript.

This program, called Rosetta uses the CMU phonetic dictionairy for
conversion.

You can get Rosetta for free at
http://www.geocities.com/andy_callaway/

I once messed around a bit by editing the CMU dictionairy provided
with the program, using a 7-bit text-editor, such as Editpad.

A few nights ago I got this great idea: using the sound change
applier available at zompist.com (ok, it's not meant for this, but it
might still work) we might perhaps be able to convert the phonetics
into full quikscript with short forms and alternative characters. The
sound-change applier can change characters into different ones using
various rules.

If throught various conversions and other work we can get such a
dictionairy to work for Rosetta, or another program, we can
automatically convert texts to quikscript!

Now unfortunately I don't have the programming skills to do this,
nevertheless, I will try to help you if I can.

If I am unclear, please ask me for clarification. I am at school now
trying to type this message before the bell will ring.

NOTE: I do not want to create a standard for writing Quikscript in. I
have suggested creating a conversion program once, and was
misunderstood. Quikscript is to be written just like how you
pronounce
it.

Ewout Stam
--- pgabhart <pgabhart@...> wrote: > Welcome to all new
members of the group and hello again to those
> who

> To give you some idea of what I am talking about: Here are several
>
> things I would like to see appear on this site.
> 1. A copy of the Quikscript manual. It is not copyrighted so
> there
> is no legal prohibition I am aware of that would prevent us from
> posting it.
> 2. Texts written in Read's Alphabet. These should be varying
> lengths and levels of complexity. They could be original or copies
>
> of literary works in the public domain.
> 3. A practice area for people to write back and forth to each
> other
> in Read's Alphabet to gain experience in reading other people's
> script. I must admit that even after years of occasional use, I am
>
> not as fluent at reading Read's Alphabet as I am at reading roman.
>
> Practice makes perfect, after all. I read roman everyday. I
> cannot
> say that about Read's Alphabet. It is hard to get practice when
> the
> only person that knows the script is yourself. I know by
> experience,
> it is not easy to get casual acquaintances to learn Read's
> Alphabet,
> but the internet gives us the chance to reach people from around
> the
> globe who are intellectually curious. The internet gives us an
> inexpensive platform that could spread the word to others.
> 4. Have all explanatory notes written in both roman and Read's
> Alphabet just as Androcles was printed in roman and Shavian.

I was planning to write both something about Shavian for Dutch people
and something about Quikscript in English. There are not many
quikscript websites around.

Soon I will have two weekends almost fully to myself. When I'm bored,
I'll try to create a Quikscript page.

My page already hosts some stuff. The 'Writing English with Cyrillic
script' definitely needs fixing, though. The pictures are unclear.

Take a look already at http://teraiten.cjb.net/

__________________________________________________
